div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,666] ALEXANDRIA, MONDAY, JANUARY 21, 1907. [EIGHT PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Deutsche Levante-Linie.
div.p: Mail and Passenger Steamships. Regular Service fortnightly from HAMBURG weekly from ANTWERP; every 4 weeks from Bordeaux direct to Alexandria; homewards every 2 weeks from Alexandria for Rotterdam and Hamburg. Goods forwarded at through-ates from all German Railway Stations on direct Billa of Lading to Alexandria, Cairo, Syria, etc. Special facilities for conveyance of cotton, etc from Alexandria via Rotterdam and Hamburg to German manufacturing towns.
Steamers AT ALEXANDRIA.
S.S. Lys now in port discharging will sail for Piraeus
S.S. Tinos for Rotterdam & Hamburg on or about the 29.
Expect. Jan. 24 SS. Paros from Antwerp.-Jan. 30 S.S. Enos-trom, Hamburg.
For tariff and particulars apply to ADOLPHE STROSS, Alexandria, Agent.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Snakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hedeirab. Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah at call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice Trieste. Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria Saturdays 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi Tuesdays 5 a.m. in time for Express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival at Trieste Wednesdays about 11 a.m. connecting with the Train de Luxe, Trieste-Vienna Ostende. Passengers reach London Fridays 4:50 p.m.
Steamer leaves Alexandria every Thursday 10 a.m.

div.head: Calvert's Carbolic Toilet Soap
div.p: Ensures a Clear, Soft Skin.

It is pure throughout, fragrantly perfumed, emollient, and antisceptic, (10% crystal carbolic). It quickly removes dust and dirt, takes away the unpleasant effects of perspiration, and leaves instead a delicious feeling of thorough purification.

p.hi: Sold by local Chemists and Storekeepers.

div.p: Made by F.C. Calvert & Co., Manchester, Eng.

div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL, Cairo
div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. Stands in its own grounds with garden and lawn tennis grounds at back. Over 350 rooms and 5 saloons. Magnificent salle à manger. Handsome covered promenade verandah, 80 yards long. Highest class cuisine, electric light throughout, and lifts. English comforts. Rooms and apartments at prices to suit everyone. For further particulars apply to GENERAL MANAGER, Cairo.

div.head: The George Nungovich Hotels.
div.p: GRAND HOTEL, HELOUAN.- Finest and most luxurious Hotel near Cairo. Patronised by Royalty. Moderate charges

HOTEL DES BAINS.- Most comfortable hotel. oppraite the Baths Pension from P.T. 40. Attached to the above hotels and specially developed Golf Links (18 holes) with Kngliah Professional. Own Golf House in the desert.
SULPHUR BATH ESTABLISHMENT.- Sulphur water at onger than any in Europe. EIght European Masse

div.head: NEW VICTORIA HOTEL,
div.p: Open all the year round.
San Stefano, Near Alexandria, Halt No. 2.

Specially built in 1904 for a class Hotel with every modern comfort. Magnificent Dining room, Saloons, Smoking room, largo Verandahs and Garden. Electric light. MODERATE CHARGES. Ten minutes by carriage or Palais tram from Sidi Gaber.—Special terms for Government Officials and Officers of the Army of Occupation. C. F. RAISIG. Manager.
RESTAURANT AND BAR OPEN TO NON-RESIDENTS.

div.head: GHEZIREH PALACE HOTEL
div.p: On the bank of the Nile. Formerly a part of the Khadive Iswail. Transformed into a luxurious hotel.
SPLENDID PARK.
Renowned for its afternoon teas on the west Balcony overlooking the Park. Excellen Tsigane Orchestra. Motor car running to Shepheard;s Hotel and vice versa.

div.head: CAIRO-SAVOY HOTEL>
div.p: IS NOW OPEN.

div.head: Grand Hotel, Khartoum.
div.p: The only First Class Hotel at Khartoum prettily situated in its extensive Palm Gardens on the Bank of the Blue Nile, with commanding views from the terrace of the Hotel over the Blue and White Nile. Omdurman and the Battlefields of Kerreri.
Entirely re-built enlarged and refurnished in 1906; replete with all modern European comforts.
Electric Light, Steam Laundry, Lawn-Tennis, Stabling, Boating own farm and Dairy products Cosmopolitan Cuisine, European service.
Terms:-From P.T. 100 to 125 per person and per day. Special terms for a prolonged stay.
8761-31-08 G. OTTO BOOK Manager

div.head: Gordon Motel, Khartoum.
div.p: Open in November.

Most comfortable and best appointed Hotel in town. Central situation, affording splendid view. No mosquitoes. Verandah, music and varied amusements. Electric Light. Carriages at landing stage at tourists disposal. Cellar renowned.
BEST CUISINE.- OPEN ALL THE YEAR ROUND. 29113-31-3-907

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT
div.p: Kom-el-Nadoura Observatory

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: Yesterday was a fine day, the weather being of a bracing character. During the night it became bery cold and squally, and the day opens dull and cheerless, a moderate gale blowing, and the temperature being low.

div.head: Tyrol.
div.p: Weissenstein Castle (340 feet). First-class. Private Hotel, near Windisch-Matrei station, Lienz. (Easily reached from Trieste or Venice.) Bracing air. Good mountaineering centre. Tennis. Fishing. Photos and Prospectuses at "Egyptian Gazette" office, Cairo

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette.
div.p: The English Daily Newspaper.
Established 1880.
Editor and Manager - - R. Snelling.
Price: ONE PIASTRE TARIFF.
Monday, January 21, 1907
OUR NATIONAL PROSPERITY.

The figures of our foreign trade for the year, and of our rrevenue for the nine months ending on December 31 enable us to form some estimate of our national prosperity. They are, says the "Spectator," sufficient remarkable to startle even the most optimistic.

For the first time in our history the total volume of oar foreign trade largely, exceeds the enormous figure of one thousand million sterling. Imports have increased by 7.6 per -cent., exports by 13.9 per cent., and the reexport trade by 9.5 per cent To give the figures : — The total value of imports was £607,998,000, an increase of £42,968,000 over those of the preceding-year ; exports reached £375,673,000, an increase of £45,856,000; while re-exports were £85,163,000, an increase of £7,383,000. The details, are as satisfactory as the totals. Among the imports, it is raw material and articles mainly or wholly manufactured in which the chief increase lies, the advance being over 12 per cent. Among the exports, the growing items are largely articles wholly or mainly manufactured, the increase being 13.5 per cent. To take one item, the increase in the export of iron and steel is 25 per cent in value and 26 per cent in quantity.

Nor has the first impression made by these Returns to be corrected by much writing down on account of increased prices. It is true that the prices of many articles and commodities were higher last year than the year before but the general rise in prices is estimated at only 6 per cent, which leaves an ample, margin for quantitative increase. Many conclusions may be drawn from these figures, but one is insistent We are experiencing an unexampled ware of prosperity. Free-trader and Tariff Reformer alike can make but the one deduction. The increase in the imports of raw material and partially manufactured goods, and in the export of wholly or partially manufactured goods, shews that during the past year there has been a high pressure laid upon our producing activity. The demand has forced an expansion of supply. The Tariff Reformer may argue, as the "Times" does, that the dumping of iron has ceased because America is too prosperous and is unable to supply her own requirements, or that we are relieved of some Continental competition because trade is so good with our neighbeurs.The “Spectator” prefers to put it that a general wave of prosperity is passing over the world, and that our existing economic system enables us to take full advantage of it.

The Revenue Returns for the last nine onths are equally comforting. The increase over the corresponding period , in 1905 is £1,497,800. The Chancellor of the Exchequer, having in view the lowering of the duty on tea and the repeal of the duty jon coal, calculated to receive in 1906-7 £1,223.000 less than in. 190545. To take the separate items :— There wqs an estimated decrease of £2,245,000 ip Customs. But up to date the decrease has only been £674,000) and even if wo arsume that this item will decline during the current quarter by another £700,000; the total decrease will still fall far short of the estimate. Excise, estimated to decrease by £30,000, shows for the nine months an increase of £107,000. The Death-duties were, assumed t> grow by £230,000, but the actual growth during threo-querters of the financial year has been £1,495,000. The increase in the Income-tax Returns was patat £150,000 ; it is already £167,000 And in "miscellaneous items" an estimated deficit oh the year of ,£13,000 haa been changed to an increase on the nine months of £336,800. One or two items, such as stamps, show more than their eitimated decrease, and-it looks as if the Post Office and Telegraph receipts might fall short of their estimated increase. But these are minor figures com paled with the great totals of incroase. Mr Asquith can scarcely avoid having in hand at the end.of the financial year a balance over his estimates of something between £2,000,000 and £3,000,000, and if he succeeds in effecting certain savings in expenditure, as seems probable, he may have a surplus of from £6,000,000 to £6,000.000 At present, of course, the trade prosperity is not lully rejected in the Revenue Returns, except to some small degree in Customs. But a prosperous commerce, high wages, and continuous employment are bound very-soon to give a new elasticity to the revenue and next year we may look to see its effects. It is true that the enormous receipts from .Death-loties last year were rather in the bature of a windfall, arid that millionaires cannot be expected to die with such regularity and profusion in every financial year. The objection is fair, but it must not be pressed too for. It seems to us that evegy Chancellor of the Exchequer is justified in Hooking for much larger receipts from the Death-duties during he coming decade than have accrued during he past The great fortunes have been most f them made within the last thirty years, and heir possessors are only just beginning to dirt Ve should not be surprised to see the Death-utiea double their yield during the next wenty years.
Tour Eiffel Music Hall.
The "Sporting Trin" of English singers and dancers made a successful debut at this theatre last night.
Quarantine In Turkey.
A telegram from Constantinople states that arrivals from Port Said are subject to a medical examination.
Council of Ministers.
The Council of Ministers will meet on Tuesday aftenoon at Aberdeen Palace under the presidency of the Khedive.
The Weather.

Owing to the high sea running outside the harbour pass, bessels were unable to enter the port this afternoon. The black flag is flying over Komel Nadoura, which indicates that the pilot cannot leave the harbour.
Visit of Japanese Squadron.

A Japanese Squadron which is on its way to Great Britain on an official visit is due at Suez in the early party of February. It is not yet known whether the Admiral and his staff will go to Cairo to be received by the Khedive.
Five Days on a Desert Island.

An Ottoman sailing ship which lately left this port for Scio, in ballast was surprised by a squall and sunk off the isle of Poffs. The master and crew of six reached shore in the ship's boat. The islet is barren and for five days they were without food. They were picked up by a saiiling ship from Simi.
Kourban Beyram.

The Ministry of War has issued orders for salnes to be fired on Wednesday afternooon, and on each of the following four days, on the occasion of Kourban Beyram The Khedive will attend Beyraum prayers early on Thursday morning at Koub eh Mosque. A salute of 21 guns will the be fired from the Citadel and Abbassieh barracks.
Arrival of Caronia.

The Cunard liner Caronia arrived here on Saturday afternoon from New York and Naples, with a large number or tourists. A special train was in waiting on the quay and left at 6 p.m. for Cairo with most of the passengers; others left for Palestine by the Khedivial Mail steamer, while a few preferred to remain in Alexandria. The Caronia sailed yesterday at 3 p.m. for New York via Fiuume and Naples.

div.head: EDUCATION IN EGYPT.
div.p: Mr. Alured Bell write to the "Morning Post": Sir,- As your interesting interview with Mr. Sidney Wellls the new Director-General of education in Egypt, throws a good deal of light on one department of the British administation, may I be permitted the opportunity of emphasising a few points necessarily ignored io the impres-ionist opinion of a stranger to the country.

Tha national good wishes wi1l, accompany the ex Principal of the Battersen Polytechnic in bis mission for the advancement of the Egyptian youth in technical education, but it is no disparagement to him to say that no new mantle can overshadow the remarkable education regime instituted by Lord Cromer in 1890, and conducted with conspicnous success by Mr. Donglas Dunlop, the Inspector General of Egyptian Education. I remember the time when, for instance, tbe proportion of pupils in tte Government schools learning French and English was, respectively. 80 and 20 per cent.; it is now, I believe. the other way round, namely, 15 and 85 per cent, in favour ot tha English language. All the superior colleges of which Mr. Wells speaks, such as the Schools of Agriculture, Law, Medicine, and Engineering, have been founded under the "old" regime, and Lord Cromer has given expression to his innate missionary genius in promoting the entirely un-Mohamedan cult of female education by establishing schools for Egyptian girls. The progress of the Egyptian youth in technical educaiton is, in my humble opinion, of far less moment than their progress in morality, logic, citizenship, and government, and the basis of these things has been well and truly laid during the last sixteen years. As a proof of this I would advance the improvement in the character of the Egyptian Government employees, the great increase in the publishing and clientele of native newspapers, and the really remarkable tendency in the higher social circles towards monogamy and the disuse of female seclusion.

The influence of the Oxford and Cambridge graduates whom Mr. Dunlop has gathered round him as professors in the schools cannot be overestimated-it is as real and permanent an influence as that acknowledged of his own masters by the English public school boy. In a word deep inroads have been made in the Oriental habit-of thought; Western, even British, ideas have been inculcated; and it is on this groundwork that Mr. Wells will construct his superior technical edifice. Lest he should, in his enthusiasm, be too anxious for immediate results, may I venture to remind him of the Arab proberb, "Harry is the Devil, slowness is of God."

div.head: KIAMIL PASHA'S CASE.
div.p: MUSSULMANS AND BRITAIN.
(Gazette's Special Service.)
LONDON January 21.

The "Times" commenting on Kiamil Pasha's dismissal, remarks that the fact of the late Grand Vizier's taking refuge in the British Consulate at Smyrnam and the Sultan according to British demands for his safety affordss striking tribute to British reputataion amoung the Muasnlman population. The "Spectator" says that this shows that the British flag is still regarded in the Turkish Empire aas a protection to those standing in fear of injustice.
CONSTANTINOPLE January 20.
Kimil Pasha has arrived and went straight to Yildiz Kiosk. Haveas

The reasons to which our Stamboul Correspondent attributes the dismissal of the Vali of Aidin are that his son, Rear-Admiral Said Pasha now in exile at Jerusalem, corresponded with brigands in the bilayet, a state of things which Kiamil Pasha was too old to prevent.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN UNIVERSITY.
div.p: Kassim Bey Assem, acting president of the committee of the proposed university, informed the committee at their meeting on Saturday that the Khedive had graciously agreed to place the cheme under his Highness's patronage, and to appoint the Heir Apparent as honorary president of the committee, promising to select a Price of the Khedivial family as president. The committee is receiving small subscription from the pupils of Government schools.

div.head: PRINCE OF UDINA'S VISIT
div.p: H.R.H. the Prince of Udina attended the performance of "Gli Ugonotti" on Saturday evening at the Zizinia Theatre being accomodated in the box of H.E. the Governor, who was also present. After the performance his Royal Highness was the guest of the Governor at supper at the New Khedivial Hotel. Marqnis di Soragno, the Italian Consul, Chabalier Morenco, commandmant of the ornier Calabria, and the Beneduccdi Bey secretary to the Governor. were also the guests of Mustapha Pa-ha Ibady.

As already announced an "At Home" will be given by the Italian colony in Alexandria at 5 p.m. or Friday next at the New Khedivial Hotel in honour of the Prince of Udina and the officers of the Calabria.

div.head: FUNERAL OF DEAN BUTCHER.
div.p: Manifestations of the deepest sympathy marked the funeral of the late Dean Butcher on Saturday At 3 p.m. the coffin, wrapped in the Union Jack, was borne on the shoulders of eight men of the Intri-killing Fusiliers from Church House to the proch of Al Saints' Church, and was carried to the charcoal, preceded by the choir, while "Oh rest in the Lord" E.j.b) was played. After the effident was placed in the chanc flowers were strewn on it by the ladies of the choir, and hun No. 508 was sure, followed by the 90th psalm. The R v. J. T Burns read the lesson from Corinthane, after which "Nune Dimittis" was sung, and the congregation stood while the Dead March in Sanl was played. On leaving the church the coffin was placed on a gun carriage and drawn by black horses and preceded by an escort of Military Mounted Police. On its arrival at the cemetery eight men of the K.O.S.B. carried the coffin to the graveside, preceded by the choir singing "Now the labourer's task is o'er." The enmmittal service was conducted by Bishop Ridley, sud on its conclusion the members of the choir dropped sprigs of cypress on the coffin, and then sang as a recessional, "On the Resurrection Morning." The chief mourners were Mrs. Butcher who was accompanied by Mr. Dou Boulay, and Mr. and Mrs. Possman. Many beautiful wreaths were sent, and the services, both at All Saint's and at the cemetary, were attended by nearly all the British residents of Cairo and several members of the Coptic churches.

div.head: NEW BANK FOR CAIRO.
div.p: Yet another new bank is, we learn, about to be established in the Capital. Mr. Ben Lassin, who has been iin the employ of the Anglo Egyptian Bacnk for the past ten years, and who was lately acting as assistant manager in Cairo, is servering his connection with that bank next month and opening a private banking firm with a capital of L.E. 100,000 in conjunction with Mr. Maurice Ades. of Mesra. Mansour & Ades, and Mr. Humbert Jabes, of Messrs. Haim Jabes & Figli.

div.head: MR. Robertsono, M.P.
div.p: Mr. J.M. Robertson, M.P., visited the Ministry of Education on Saturday, and had an interview with Mr. Dunlop, Adviser to the Ministry, and Mr. Boyd Carpenter, inspector. Afterwards he visited the Nasrieh school, and had a long converstaion with the headmaster of the latter. In the afternoon the M.P. wernt to Mastariahm where he took the house of Saved Hassan Moussa. El-Akkad. Mr. Robart on yesterday visited some other school kutabs in Cairo belonging to the government.

div.head: THE RUSSIAN AGITATION.
div.p: YESTERDAY'S SCENES IN ALEXANDRIA.

To all outward appearance, Alexandria, ordinarily is peaceful on a Sunday, seemed yesterday to be in the very throes of a revolution. The agitation in favour of the release of three Russian refugees, who have been arrested by the police on a very grave charge, and to which we referred on Saturday, yesterday assumed much more serious proportions than were warranted by the facts of the cave. Reedless of the diplomatic difficulties which stand in the way of such a step, and regardless of the Capitulations, a large proportion of the European population of Alexandria is clamouring for the release of thrre Russian revolutionaries, whose extradition they wish to prevent—on grounds which are purely sentimental. However much we may sympathise with the Russian revolutionaries in their strnggle with despotism, any movement such as the present is greatly to be deprecated, and we are surprised to see that a local contemporary has gone to such extreme lengths in fanning an agitation which can be prodcotive ol no good.
The scenes in the streets of Alexandria both on Saturday and yesterday were deplorable.

On Saturday, on a rumour being spread that the refugees had been embarked on the Russian steamer for Odessa, a crowd of'manifestanta" nade their way to the quay, shouting “Vive la liberty," and boarded the vessel with the object of discovering whether the rumour was true. As it happened it was not, but some ill-advised person in authority called out the Pire Brigade to deal with the demonstrators. This measure only aggravated the situation, and gave rise to incidents which might have been avoided by the exercise of more discretion. The crowd attacked the Fire Brigade and did some damage to the engine and hoses, while some horse play was indulged in. Order was only restored by the arrival of H B. the Governor, who gave his personal assurance that the prisoners were safe in custody, and that they would not bo deported before a full enquiry was held into the case.

Yesterday something of the natnre of an attack was made on the Russian Consulate in Ramleh-boulevard, ths consulate shield being torn down. A cordon of police was afterwards formed round the consulate and traffic stopped iu that part if the boalevard. The efforts ot the polioe to keep people away from the vicinity of the building resulted in several scuffles, but nothing of a very serious character happened, and after nightfall the street returned its normal aspect, two sentries being left posted at the consulate door. Several demonstrations took plsce in various parts if the city daring the day, no'allly at the Bourse, where M Alfred Campos, as one of the leaders of the agitation, connseled calm, wisely stating that their object could not be attained by resort to force but by peaceful means.

Meantime the prisoners are incarcerated at Hadra prison, awaiting the decision of the authorities. We believe that a solution of the dlfficulty will be foundd in their being sent to one European port.

div.head: Zizinia Theatre
div.p: Meyervere's fine old opera "Qli Ugnnotti” was very well given on Saturday night: it was the high level of the performances which we have yet seen. Sig. Marchi Emilio is a most sympathetic Reoul, and, though laboring ’ under 'he disadvantage of a heavy cold, filled his exacting part admirably. We hope to see no more empty houses during his adjourn in Alexandria. Signs. de Lerma Matilde's Valentins is a convincing combination ' of voice and acting ; and her difficult and involved gymnastics in the opper compass were most cleverly and accurately handled by Sig Finizi Magrini. We will not deny, however, that we feel, as it were, born out of due time for there intricate cadences, which give one, like the longer trills in Handel's Messiah, no definite pleasure, but rather a hauting terror that the strained performer will break down, turning pathos into bathos. For the rest, Siz. Chotkowska Ladislawa made I an attractive Urbano and as for Marcello—

we are almost tired of praising Sig. Walter Carlo, who never disappoints us. The orchestra ’ showed to great advantage, especially in the difficult viola passages in Act I ; and here , at the risk of boring by repeated insistence on our point, we cannot help remarking once again that we do not want to hear either the conductor's mellow tones or the innuating asides of the prompter; singly, they are distictly audible in unison, they carry all before them.
again that we do not want to hear either the condootor’s mellow tones or the indnuatiog asides of the prompter ; singly, they are di-tinotly audib'e;iu unison, thry carry all btfire them.

div.head: TRIPOLI IN BARBARY.
div.p: The administrative and financial reorganization of the sanjak of Benghzi has been decided on. THe eight nahiehs into which the sarjak is divided are to be abolished, and three xazas and a new nahieh will be formed in their stead. A special corps of five inspectors and fifty tax collectors will be appointed to replace the present fiscal system which the sarjak enjoy.

div.head: CAIRO'S GARDEN CITY.
div.p: Several of the very best plots of this estate are offered, at very reasonable rates, by Mr. C. Aquilina, Carlton Hotel, Bulkeley.

div.head: Winter Palace Hotel
div.p: LUXOR'S NEW HOSTERLY.
(From Our Special Correspondent.)
Luxor Monday.

Tha inaugural proceeding at the new Winter Palace Hotel have been carried out with such delightful entertainment and on such a lavish scale that everyone who has partaken of the hospitality offered him is filled with regret at their termination. Saturday's programme included the visit to the far famed Tombs of the Kings for those who were energetically inclined, and a most perfect lunch was served to those who preferred to spend their morning exploring the various objects ot interest in the immediate neighbourhood.

During the afternoon the workmen and builders who had labored so conscientiously at their task were collected in the still unfinished garden at the back of the hotel and there received the reward of their toil in the shape of most congratulatory speeches from Mr. E. A. Harrison and Mr. Splenon and substantial gifts, doles of meat being distributed to the men and handsome watches being presented to those who had control of the various gangs. Mr. Harrison indeed proved the presiding spirit at these, as at the subsequent proceedings, being generous in the thanks he accorded to those who had borne the burden and heat of the day, and hospitable to a degree to all who, were present. As chairman of the Upper Egypt Hotels Co., he voiced his committee in its expression of hope for a successful future. Mr. Harrison has assuredly done his best to make that future a certainty. The dinner hour was fixed for 7.30 pm., and the restaurant, brilliantly lighted and tastefully decorated, was soon filled with guests. A long T-shaped table was surrounded by notabilities from Cairo and the neighbourhood and representatives of the press. We have not space to give the names of those who were present. Enough that the dinner was admirable, and the future visitors of the hotel should have the utmost confidence in the cuisine. Speeches, dancing, bridge, and conversation followed the dinner, and in the course of the whole of our Egyptian experience we have never known an evening in which hospitality and informality were so delightfully blended, and we have no hesitation in saying that if the Winter Palace Hotel continues as it has begun it will be the most popular house of entertaiment in the length and breadth of Egypt. The only cause for regret during the above-mentioned proceedings was the absence of M. Pagnon, who, as proprietor of Pagnon's Hotels and latterly as managing director of the Upper Egypt Hotels, has proved himself to be one of the leading and most successful personalities in Egypt.

div.head: NOTES FROM LUXOR.
div.p: TOWN TEEMING WITH TOURISTS.
(From Our Correspondent.)
Luxor, January 18.

Luxor is awake! The town teems with tourists. Dahavashs are daily arriving. The Luxor and Savoy Hotels are full, and the steamers of Messra. Thos. Cook and Son and the Hamburg and Anglo-American Companies line the river wharves, bearing their full complement of passengers, and making the froont hum with life.

Before these lines are in print, another will be added to the list of hostelries at this popular resort, and the "Winter Palace Hotel" will have started on its career. The bookings for rooms are numerous, and the manager looks forward confidently to a successful and a long continued season.

The weather has been delightful. Even during the heat-wave that prevailed further South a short time ago Luxor escaped it's intenisity, and now the north wind has arrived, and, after a short break, the sun is once more tempering its keenness, and warming the air as only Egyptian sunshine in January can. It is well known to visitors who come to Luxor again and again, that here is no climate of extremes. It is unusual to have either intensely hot, or very cold weather, during the winter season, and its situation is particularly sheltered from high winds.

Regular weekly Gymkhanas are now being held on the race-course just outside the town. The third meeting of the season, on Thursday last, was a most successful one. The usual native races were much appreciated by the many strangers who filled the the grand-stand, while the three races for visitors: gentlemen's donkey race, ladies' race, and goolsh-pegging were well patronised and caused much amusement both for riders and spectators. Baron Heintze, a well known visitor to Luxor, carried off the 1st prize at the goolabs, and was also second in the donkey race.

A very enjoyable entertainment was given on Thurdsay evening on board the Rameses III., when some extremely clever ticks of cards and sleight of-hand were shown by Sir Alfred Cooperm who is making the Nile trip with his son. Some charming music was also provided, the singing of Miss Reibold being a specially great treat to those privileged to hear her. A collection was made at the end of the evening for the Luxor Hospital for natives, which will no doubt benefit to a considerable exxtent by the happy thought of those who organised the show.

Among the visitors now at the Luxor Hotel are Bishop and Mrs. Whitehead of Madras, who are making a stay in Egypt on their way to India, and Sir Benjamin Stone, M.P. for East Birmingham, and well-known as a traveller and as a clever and enthusiastic photographer.

div.head: FAYOUM RACES.
div.p: F.R.C.'s FIRST MEETING.
(From Our Correspondent.)

THe first meeting of the Fayoum Racing Club on their new course took place on Friday, and proved an unqualified success, the attendance being extremely large and some 42 horses entering for the five races on the programme. Amon those present were the Adviser to the Ministry of the Interior and Lady Vicotira Machell, Captain Proheroe Smisth and practically all the Englishmen connected any way with the province; while of the native notables frew if any were absent.
The club has erected two pulbic stands and a third class enclosure, besides a private stand; stalls are provided for 30 houses and a parimutual and a buffet are included.

Anybody in serach of a boy who can ride 5 stone would find a treasure in the rider of the winner of the third and fourth races. Though oonly a small Sudannee boy of 10 years he rides with all the confidence of a crack light weight at home, and with no little judgment. The following were the resutls of the races:-
The Karoun Stakes value P.T. 800.
Abdul Wahed and Ahmed Fathi's Gazelle Mahomed Salah's Matrowie Mahomed Basil's Assiury
13 started. Won easily by three length. The Club Stakes. value P.T. 600. Abdul Washed and Ahmed Fatbi's Fritz Moward O'eilb's Kaahf
Shek Yesseen Abouel Mckaram's Tyar 6 ran. Fritz made practically all the running and won in a canter by three lengths.
The Fayoum Stakes value P.T. 2500.
Mahomed el Basil's Fayoum 1
Mahomed Salah's Matrowie 2
Mahomed Abdul Hallaq's Farhan 3

5 ran. At the end of the first mile Matrowie seemed to have the race in hand, catching up the leaders when akad without apparent effort, but entering the straight Fayoum drew further away at every stride and won as he liked by 8 lengths.
The Pyramid Stakes value P.T. 1,000.
Mohamed Amin's Maurice 1
Moward Koleib's Ka-hf 2
Homamed Aly Byad's Kouisan

9 ran. a very hot pace soon produced a long tail with Kousan leading; in the straight Kashf and Maurice both passed him, and maintaining his effort the latter won a good race all out by a length and a half.

The fifth race somewhat failed in its object, it being intended for bona fide fellaheen, with a special prize to the omdeh of the village from which the winning horse came. Unfortunately I became known that the Moudir had presented a gold watch for the winning omdeh, and though three horses were sent back at the post out of the 15, the first three horses in the race should also have been disqualified. Many difficulties occurred, but the prizes were eventually awarded them.

The thank of the committee are especially due to Lady Victoria Machell for kindly distributing the prizes, to the Moudir for his constant supervision of the arrangements, and to Ahmed Eff Farhion whom most of the work has fallen Mr. Miller kindly acted as starter, and Captain Prothero Smith as judge.

div.head: FAYOUM NOTES.
div.p: Our correspondent at Medinatel Fayoum compalins of the indolence of the Municipality whose intertia is responsible for the lack of drinking water. He suggests artesian wells to replace the present supply of stagnant water. The native members of the Municipality, he says, do not pay much attention to sanitary rules, and their European colleagues have no time to see the city's welfare.
Bountiful rains have fallen in the Fayoum, and the crops have benefited thereby.
Upwards of twelve thousand men are engaged on contract works in the province.
During 1906 the Fayoum branch of the Agricultural Bank received about L.E. 38000, and the Cre lit Foncier and other tanks collectiverly L.E. 50,000

Our Correspondent remarks upon M. Machell's great popularity in the Fayoum. The Adviser to the Ministry of the Interior held a reception there last wekk, and afterwards visited the districs of Abexa, Abbhsway and Shwashia. He was acompanied by Lady Victoria Machell.

div.head: SUDAN NEWS.
div.p: A Kassala correspndent states that measles are still raging in the lines of the 11th Battalion, about 75 children suffering from the disease. In the town only one case is reported.
The Gash cultivation is at its, especially the cotton cultivation. The pre eat price is P.T. 80 per kantar.
Mr. Tottenham, Inspector of Irrigation, arrived in Kassala on the 28th ulto in order to organize this year's operations.

div.head: BECK and Co's Pilsener Beer
div.p: FEARS NO HONEST COMPETITION FOR QUALITY.
N.B.-Inferior Brands now being offered to
Managers of certain good circles. Beware of evilly disposed competition running down this very.
SUPERIOR BRAND OF BEER

div.head: Notice for Tourists
div.p: MOERIS HOTEL (on Lake Karoun). Very comfortable. Good shooting Patronised by Princess of Battenberg, Prince of Sweden, etc.
For particulars apply: A. TASCO, Proprietor, also proprietor of Grand Hotel Karoun, Fayoum.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: General Bullock, C.B, accompanied by Col. Cuthhert is coming down to Alexandria today and will put up at the Khedivial Hotel.
Mustapha Pasha Kamel arrived in Cairo yesterday mroning on his return from Europe, accompanied by his friend Muhamed Farid Bey.
The engagement is announced of Mr. Arthur Caleja and Mlle Gilda Lombardi Boccia.

The following passengers travelled to Luxor by the train de luxe on Friday night to attend the inauguration of the Winter Palace Hotel:- Mr. Busbyy, Mr. R Snelling, Mr. B. Manfield, Mr. R. Colrat, Mr. E Dicey, Mr. di Pompeo. Comte de Collato, Mr. G. Merzhasch. Mr. O Food, Mr. G. Bayssie, Mr. P. Manse. Mr. W. Jones Mr. H. Aspinall. the Editor of "Les Pyramides," the Editor of El Ahram," the Editor of "Al Moksttam," Mr. and Mrs. Tite. Mr. Marshall Hewat, Mr. E. A. Harrison, Mr. and Mrs. Mayne.

Among the prominent New Yorkers who arrived at Alexandria on Saturday by the Caronia are: Mr. Edwin C.A. kinson, Mr. and Mrs James H. Aldrich, Dr Edward P. Brewer, Mr George K. Baker, Miss Helen Colesmore, Mr. Aaron M. Crane. Mr. W F. Doty. American Consul at Tabriz. Persia; Mr. Henry T. Farrar. Mr and Mrs. Hugh A. Murray. Mr. and Mrs. W.H. Moffit.
